glossary.name: AE86
glossary.description: A lightweight, rear-wheel-drive car made by Toyota, iconic in drift culture. Known as the Toyota Corolla Levin or Sprinter Trueno, it gained popularity through the 'Initial D' series.

glossary.name: Drift
glossary.description: A driving technique where the driver intentionally oversteers, causing loss of traction in the rear wheels while maintaining control. It originated in Japan and became a global motorsport phenomenon.

glossary.name: RB26DETT
glossary.description: An inline-six twin-turbocharged engine produced by Nissan, primarily used in the Skyline GT-R models R32, R33, and R34. Renowned for its performance and tunability.

glossary.name: 2JZ-GTE
glossary.description: A legendary inline-six twin-turbocharged engine from Toyota, used in the Mk4 Toyota Supra. It is celebrated for its incredible strength and aftermarket tuning potential.

glossary.name: Touge
glossary.description: Japanese term for mountain passes, where spirited driving and unofficial road races occur. These routes often feature tight corners and elevation changes, ideal for drifting.

glossary.name: RWD
glossary.description: Rear-Wheel Drive, a drivetrain layout where power is delivered to the rear wheels. It is preferred for drifting and high-performance driving due to improved weight distribution.

glossary.name: Kaido Racer
glossary.description: A style of Japanese car modification inspired by race cars from the 1970s and 1980s. Characterized by exaggerated aero kits, bright colors, and loud exhaust systems.

glossary.name: Itasha
glossary.description: A Japanese car decoration trend where vehicles are adorned with anime, manga, or video game character decals. Itasha translates to 'painful car,' referencing the cost or visual impact.

glossary.name: Initial D
glossary.description: A popular manga and anime series that brought global fame to Japanese street racing and drifting culture. It features iconic cars like the AE86 and Nissan GT-R.

glossary.name: Silvia
glossary.description: A series of sport coupes produced by Nissan, especially the S13, S14, and S15 models. They are highly regarded in the drifting community.

glossary.name: Spoon Sports
glossary.description: A famous Japanese tuning company specializing in Honda vehicles. Known for their high-performance parts and modifications.

glossary.name: Boso Exhaust
glossary.description: An exaggerated exhaust pipe style associated with Bosozoku culture, characterized by long, angled, or stacked pipes.

glossary.name: VTEC
glossary.description: Variable Valve Timing and Lift Electronic Control, Honda's innovative engine technology that optimizes performance and efficiency at different RPMs.

glossary.name: GT Wing
glossary.description: A large rear wing added to cars for aerodynamic stability at high speeds. Commonly seen on modified cars in motorsport.

glossary.name: Rocket Bunny
glossary.description: A popular Japanese aftermarket body kit brand, known for its wide-body kits and aggressive styling.

glossary.name: Wangan
glossary.description: Refers to the high-speed expressways around Tokyo Bay, famous for street racing culture. The Wangan Midnight manga and anime are set here.

glossary.name: JDM
glossary.description: Japanese Domestic Market, referring to cars and parts designed specifically for the Japanese market. JDM has become synonymous with high-quality performance and tuning.

glossary.name: Bosozoku
glossary.description: A Japanese subculture associated with rebellious motorcycle and car modification groups. Their cars are often flamboyant with loud exhausts and bold designs.

glossary.name: RX-7
glossary.description: A rotary-engine sports car made by Mazda. The FD3S model is especially beloved for its design and performance.

glossary.name: GT-R
glossary.description: Nissan's flagship performance car series, starting with the Hakosuka Skyline GT-R and continuing to the R35. Revered for speed, power, and advanced engineering.

glossary.name: AE85
glossary.description: A less powerful, front-wheel-drive version of the Toyota Corolla that shares its platform with the AE86. While less iconic, it has been the subject of drifting culture.

glossary.name: Nitto Tires
glossary.description: A leading brand of high-performance tires, especially known in drifting and motorsport circles for their grip and durability.

glossary.name: Kouki
glossary.description: Refers to the later, updated versions of cars, often with revised styling or performance upgrades. Commonly used in the context of Nissan Silvia S14 and other cars.

glossary.name: Zenki
glossary.description: Refers to the earlier, pre-facelift versions of cars, often having less refined designs or equipment compared to the 'kouki' models.

glossary.name: Turbocharger
glossary.description: A forced induction system that increases an engine's power output by compressing air and forcing it into the engine's cylinders. Popular in many high-performance JDM cars.

glossary.name: Aftermarket Parts
glossary.description: Parts and accessories made by companies other than the vehicle's original manufacturer, often used for performance enhancements, styling, or customization.
